Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. The family gathering was already underway—my daughter had sent a photo of my grandkids laughing around the table, waiting for me to join them. I’d promised my wife I wouldn’t be late this time. But here I was, standing in a line at the polling station, clutching my ID, as the election official explained the registration mix-up. “You’ll need to fill out this provisional ballot form,” she said, “and we close in ten minutes.” I could hear the expectation in her voice: follow the process, do your civic duty, don’t hold up the line. But my mind was with my family, picturing my grandson’s disappointed face if I missed his story about school. The pressure built inside me—my responsibility as a citizen pulling me one way, my promise as a grandfather tugging the other. I felt torn, wishing I could be in two places at once, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
